clean_content:
Definition / general

* Benign fibro-osseous neoplasm ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2021;20:240](33927492), [Oral Dis 2017;23:440](27387498), [Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:70](31950477), [J Stomatol Oral Maxillofac Surg 2022;123:364](33878496))* Origin is controversial but is mostly odontogenic in origin and usually arises in jaw ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2021;20:240](33927492), [Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:248](34184157))* Characterized by production of bone and cementum-like calcifications in a fibrous stroma* Usually located in the mandible during third to fourth decade of life ([Oral Dis 2017;23:440](27387498), [Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:70](31950477), [J Stomatol Oral Maxillofac Surg 2022;123:364](33878496))

Essential features

* Cemento-ossifying fibroma (COF) is a fibro-osseous lesion characterized by varied patterns of bone formation in a fibroblastic stroma ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:991](35546651))* Putatively benign lesion with very rare malignant transformation or metastasis ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:991](35546651), [Ear Nose Throat J 2023;102:24](35575211))* Cemento-ossifying fibroma is named because of its usual location in the tooth bearing region of the jaw

Terminology

* Ossifying fibroma, conventional type; cemento-ossifying fibroma; ossifying fibroma; conventional ossifying fibroma; cementifying fibroma

ICD coding

* ICD-O: [9274/0](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=88) - cemento-ossifying fibroma

Epidemiology

* Rare lesion that occurs over a broad age range, with peak incidence in third to fourth decade of life ([Oral Dis 2017;23:440](27387498), [Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:70](31950477), [J Stomatol Oral Maxillofac Surg 2022;123:364](33878496))* Has female predilection (F:M = 5:1)* Tumor is more prevalent in White people than Black people ([Oral Dis 2017;23:440](27387498))

Sites

* Mandible is most common, followed by the maxilla* Mandibular premolar and molar area have more predilection ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:70](31950477))* Maxillary lesions tend to involve antrum and canine fossa* Cemento-ossifying fibroma can be classified according to site of origin as ([Int J Surg Case Rep 2020;68:257](32199251))
        + Soft tissue counterpart is referred to as peripheral cemento-ossifying fibroma (PCOF) ([Int J Surg Case Rep 2020;68:257](32199251))+ Central cemento-ossifying fibroma (CCOF) arises from cells of periodontal ligament in the apical area ([Int J Surg Case Rep 2020;68:257](32199251))

Pathophysiology

* Multiple cemento-ossifying fibromas rarely show syndromic / inherited association and usually present at a younger age ([Case Rep Dent 2023;2023:4664619](36937223))* Hyperparathyroidism jaw tumor syndrome (HPT JT): rare autosomal dominant disease caused by mutation of the tumor suppressor gene *CDC73* that encodes for parafibromin resulting in premature truncation of parafibromin protein product; the syndrome predisposes to a triad occurrence: multiple maxillary or mandibular cemento-ossifying fibroma, parathyroid adenoma or carcinoma and renal and uterine tumors ([Int J Surg Case Rep 2020;68:257](32199251))

Etiology

* Origin of cemento-ossifying fibroma has been suggested as odontogenic or from periodontal ligament progenitor cells ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2021;20:240](33927492))* Origin of nonodontogenic lesions of similar histology arising from craniofacial bone outside the jaw is unclear ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:257](34173971))* Periodontal membrane has multipotent cells capable of forming cementum, lamellar bone and fibrous tissue ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2021;20:240](33927492))* Lesion can present as a component of hyperparathyroidism jaw tumor syndrome; 25 - 50% of patients of this syndrome develop cemento-ossifying fibroma of the jaws with the mandible as a favored site ([Case Rep Dent 2023;2023:4664619](36937223), [J Dent Sci 2020;15:426](33505612))

Clinical features

* Smaller lesions are asymptomatic* Larger / solitary lesions present as painless swelling that causes jaw expansion, facial asymmetry, tooth divergence ([Heliyon 2021;7:e07594](34337187))* Grows slowly but can reach a considerable size if left untreated ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:70](31950477))* Extension to the nasal septum, orbital floor and infraorbital foramen can be seen in larger lesions; rarely associated with the destruction of extraosseous soft tissue components ([Heliyon 2021;7:e07594](34337187))* Juvenile variant of lesion occurring at a young age is clinically aggressive and highly recurrent ([Heliyon 2021;7:e07594](34337187), [J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2021;20:240](33927492))

Diagnosis

* Diagnosis dependent on clinical, radiologic and pathologic correlation ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2021;20:240](33927492))

Laboratory

* No specific laboratory tests are available

Radiology description

* Radiological findings vary according to maturity of lesion; early lesions show well defined corticated radiolucency and over time, lesion becomes progressively more radiopaque ([Heliyon 2021;7:e07594](34337187), [BMJ Case Rep 2020;13:e239286](33372024))* Well circumscribed, unilocular lesion with centrifugal pattern of growth ([Heliyon 2021;7:e07594](34337187))* Can present as lesion with well defined sclerotic borders and is predominantly unilocular ([BMJ Case Rep 2020;13:e239286](33372024))* Larger lesions show expansion, thinning and perforation of buccal and lingual cortex and involvement of the lower border of mandible ([BMJ Case Rep 2020;13:e239286](33372024))

Radiology images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D., Thomas W. Fonner, D.M.D., Carlton Taylor, D.M.D., Firas Katabi, D.D.S. and Nish Shah, D.M.D., M.D.  

[![Radiolucency in Anterior Mandible](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith01.jpg)

Radiolucency in anterior mandible

[![Expansile lesion of mandible](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith02.jpg)

Expansile lesion of mandible

[![Cortical destruction](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith03.jpg)
 
[![Cortical destruction](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith04.jpg)

Cortical destruction

[![Root Divergence](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith05.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith05.jpg)

Root divergence

Prognostic factors

* Slow growing, benign neoplasm with no recurrence in majority of cases* Malignant transformation has been reported in a single case ([Ear Nose Throat J 2023;102:24](35575211))

Case reports

* 19 year old woman with a large maxillary cemento-ossifying fibroma superimposed with solitary bone cyst ([Int J Surg Case Rep 2020;68:257](32199251))* 30 year old man with multiple cemento-ossifying fibromas ([Case Rep Dent 2023;2023:4664619](36937223))* 45 year old man with large cemento-ossifying fibroma of the mandible involving the infratemporal and parapharyngeal spaces ([Heliyon 2021;7:e07594](34337187))

Treatment

* Treated by enucleation and curettage as it shells out easily and recurs rarely ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2021;20:240](33927492))* Untreated tumors can attain a massive size and rarely require en bloc resection ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2021;20:240](33927492))

Clinical images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Large solitary swelling obliterating buccal vestibule](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromanih005.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8318853/figure/fig1/)

Large solitary swelling obliterating buccal vestibule

[![Bony mass in maxilla](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromanih06.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10244260/figure/FIG1/)

Bony mass in maxilla

[![Intraoperative exposure of COF showing clear distinction between the lesion and healthy bone](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromanih07.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10244260/figure/FIG4/)

Distinction between lesion and healthy bone

Gross description

* Well circumscribed tumor that can be shelled out easily in one piece

Gross images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Excision](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromanih08.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10244260/figure/FIG4/)

Excision

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Well defined lesion; may have thin fibrous capsule* Well demarcated margin from surrounding normal bone* Lesion consists of variable proportion of fibrous and mineralized tissue, more heavily mineralized centrally; it shows variation in the amount and type of mineralization, even within a single lesion* Osteoblastic rimming of bone trabeculae is frequent ([J Stomatol Oral Maxillofac Surg 2022;123:364](33878496))* Stroma is fibroblastic with areas of hypercellularity and nuclear hyperchromasia* No significant atypia and mitoses are infrequent ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:70](31950477))* Woven to lamellar bone, osteoid and dense acellular or paucicellular basophilic rounded cementum-like calcifications may all be present ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:70](31950477))* Bony trabeculae may form thick anastomosing strands or fuse into large sheets centrally* Hemorrhagic cystic degeneration, resembling aneurysmal bone cyst formation, is more often found in juvenile active ossifying fibromas but has been reported in rare COFs ([J Stomatol Oral Maxillofac Surg 2022;123:364](33878496), [Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:248](34184157))* Areas resembling cemento-ossifying fibroma may be seen in psammomatoid and trabecular ossifying fibroma; cemento-ossifying fibroma may contain ossicles like psammomatoid ossifying fibroma* Cemento-ossifying fibroma with syndromic association has histology similar to that of nonsyndromic cemento-ossifying fibroma* Cemento-ossifying fibroma in gnathodiaphyseal dysplasia is at the more fibrous end of spectrum with predominantly basophilic rounded islands and droplets of acellular bone ([Head Neck Pathol 2014;8:432](25409854))

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Saira Javeed, M.B.B.S., M.Phil., Kelly Magliocca, D.D.S., M.P.H. and Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.  

[![Well circumscribed solid tumor mass](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaJaveed01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaJaveed01.jpg)

Well circumscribed solid tumor mass

[![Rounded to spherical variable sized cementum-like ossicles](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaJaveed02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaJaveed02.jpg)
 
[![Rounded to spherical variable sized cementum-like ossicles](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaJaveed03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaJaveed03.jpg)

Rounded to spherical variable sized cementum-like ossicles

[![Benign fibro-osseous proliferation](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillawhoMagliocca34.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillawhoMagliocca34.jpg)

Benign fibro-osseous proliferation

  

[![Rounded mineralized droplets](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaMagliocca01new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaMagliocca01new.jpg)

Rounded mineralized droplets

[![Fibro-osseous proliferation](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith06.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith06.jpg)

Fibro-osseous proliferation

[![Woven Bone](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith07.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith07.jpg)

Woven bone

[![Brush borders](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith08.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromaSmith08.jpg)

Brush borders

Positive stains

* Cemento-ossifying fibromas showed significant immune reactivity for [keratan sulphate](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmucins.html) (IHC is not necessary for diagnosis) ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2021;20:240](33927492))

Negative stains

* [p53](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp53.html) ([J Clin Exp Dent 2022;14:e27](35070121))* [MDM2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmdm2.html) (25%) and [CDK4](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainscdk4.html) (2%) can be seen in a subset of cases but is typically focal (≤ 10% of nuclear staining) ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:991](35546651))

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* None for sporadic cemento-ossifying fibroma* Syndromic cemento-ossifying fibroma can be identified clinically or by genetic mutations in *CDC73* (also known as *HRPT2*) ([J Dent Sci 2020;15:426](33505612), [Case Rep Dent 2023;2023:4664619](36937223))* Multiple ossifying fibromas can be associated with hyperparathyroidism jaw tumor syndrome ([Case Rep Dent 2023;2023:4664619](36937223), [J Dent Sci 2020;15:426](33505612))* Amplification of *MDM2* gene by fluorescence in situ hybridization is rarely (3%) seen in ossifying fibroma ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:991](35546651))* Positive *MDM2* amplification in craniofacial fibro-osseous lesion does not completely exclude ossifying fibroma; however, it should still raise concern for low grade osteosarcoma because this genetic event is much more common in the latter ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:991](35546651))

Molecular / cytogenetics images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![MDM2 amplification by FISH](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibromanih10.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9729456/figure/Fig2/)

*MDM2* amplification by FISH

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaossifyingfibroma_nih00.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5034632/figure/Fig1/)

*CDC73* mutations in sporadic tumors

Sample pathology report

* Mandible, enucleation and curettage:
  + Benign fibro-osseous neoplasm consistent with cemento-ossifying fibroma / ossifying fibroma (see comment)+ Comment: This is a benign fibro-osseous neoplasm that requires clinical and radiological correlation.

Differential diagnosis

* [Peripheral ossifying fibroma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityperipheralossifyingfibroma.html) ([Int J Health Sci (Qassim) 2019;13:63](31341457), [Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2022;27:e460](35717619)):
  + Reactive, inflammatory, hyperplastic growth of the gingiva+ It is the soft tissue counterpart to COF; microscopically, it is lined by mucosa and can have identical microscopic appearance* [Cemento-osseous dysplasia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillafloridcemento.html):
    + Nonneoplastic fibro-osseous lesion of tooth bearing regions+ Most common benign fibro-osseous lesion of jaws, affects middle aged women+ Patients can be managed with follow up and symptomatic treatment+ Radiology: radiolucent, radiodense or mixed, as the lesion matures becomes more radiodense and calcified+ Grossly usually received in multiple gritty fragments with tan brown color+ Microscopically identical to COF
                - Unencapsulated with variable cellular fibrous stroma and areas of loose collagen- Stroma can display osteoid, bone and cementum-like material- Mature lesion shows more calcification+ Clinical and radiographic correlation is essential to differentiate the two, especially on incisional biopsies+ An expansile variant of cemento-osseous dysplasia exists and can mimic COFs* [Chronic osteomyelitis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaCRMO.html) ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:842](31782116)):
      + Inflammatory process with a history of trauma and sinus formation+ No age or gender preference+ Treatment includes surgery to remove portions of bone that are infected or dead, followed by intravenous antibiotics given in the hospital+ Microscopically: findings are nonspecific, such as chronic inflammatory cell infiltration, bone marrow fibrosis and sclerotic bone formation* [Desmoplastic fibroma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxilladesmoplasticfibroma.html):
        + Locally aggressive fibroblastic lesion of bone+ Mostly affects mandible in people younger than 30 (mean: 16 years), no gender predilection+ Excision, recurrence is common+ Radiology: well defined without mineralization+ Grossly: firm, tan-white with rough cut surface, myxoid areas can be seen+ Microscopically
                    - Infiltrative lesion comprising fascicles of uniform myofibroblasts / fibroblasts having tapering nuclei in a collagenous to myxoid stroma- Perivascular edema and mitotic figures are present- Overt bony trabeculae or droplets absent+ IHC: [alpha smooth muscle actin (ASMA)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsalphasmoothmuscleactin.html) and [beta catenin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbetacatenin.html) positive in some cases+ Associated with activating *CTNNB1* gene / *APC* mutation* [Fibrous dysplasia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillafibrousdysplasia.html):
          + Skeletal anomaly, a disorder of growing bones+ Monostotic or polyostotic lesion, affects craniofacial bones and femur in children and adolescents, no gender predilection+ Lesions stabilize with skeletal maturation, surgical intervention in younger patients is delayed+ Radiology: radiolucent to sclerotic, ground glass appearance with indistinct borders+ Grossly: affected bone is rubbery, compressible with gritty texture+ Microscopically
                      - Has bland hypocellular appearance if the lesion is mature; can be hypercellular when the lesion is in actively growing phase- Lesion fuses with adjacent normal bone- Irregularly shaped trabeculae of bone in a background fibrous stroma- Trabeculae of woven bone are elongated and curvilinear, described as Chinese characters or letters in alphabet soup- Osteoblastic rimming absent or minimal- Retraction artifact / peritrabecular clefting often present+ Associated with *GNAS* gene mutation and McCune-Albright syndrome* [Intraosseous meningioma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cnstumormeningiomageneral.html) ([Surg Neurol Int 2021;12:485](34754535)):
            + Most common benign brain / intracranial tumors, however, intraosseous meningiomas are rare lesions accounting for < 1% of intracranial meningiomas+ Common locations are frontoparietal and orbital regions+ Surgical removal though challenging is curative+ Radiology: depending upon location, usually circumscribed with surrounding bone shell+ Microscopically: morphology is similar to dura based lesions* [Osteoblastoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaosteoblastoma.html):
              + Benign bone forming tumor+ Rare lesion, mostly affects craniofacial bones specially mandible in people in second to third decade with slight male predominance+ Can be excised however recurrences are reported after incomplete removal+ Radiology: circumscribed rounded of usually > 20 mm in size, radiolucent to radiopaque, sclerotic border; can mimic malignancy+ Grossly: multiple firm tan-white fragments+ Microscopically
                          - Lesion is composed of haphazard mineralized trabeculae of bone showing prominent osteoblastic rimming, lying in cellular fibrous stroma- Rare mitotic figures* [Osteosarcoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaosteosarcoma.html) ([J Cancer Res Ther 2018;14:471](29516945)):
                + Malignant bone tumor+ Greatest predilection for the metaphysis (femur and tibia), osteosarcoma of craniofacial bones is infrequent+ Osteosarcoma of the jaws are rare and comprise ~7% of all osteosarcoma cases+ Radiology: irregular mixed radiolucent radiopaque pattern with infiltrative margins+ Microscopically: displays features commonly found in various types of malignant neoplasms* Reference: [J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2021;20:240](33927492)

Additional references

* [Neville: Oral and Maxillofacial Pathology, 5th Edition, 2022](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0323789811/pathologyoutl-20), [WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board: Head and Neck Tumours, 5th Edition, 2024](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283245148/pathologyoutl-20)
